narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The class size is reasonably large, but the classroom is too small.
The class was very superficial, did not go into much detail in any of the topics covered.
Both the Professor and TA were very helpful and accessible, making for a nice learning environment.
This course in tropical ecology is rather theoritical than practical. We would have great if we have had a field trip to a tropical country so that to grasp hands-on experience on this course.

Questions 1&7: The Instructor and the TA of the Course were very efficient in providing us with materials as well as ensuring that we interact with those materials. The course was delivered with great enthusiasm.
Question 5: Professor was eager to engage in students questions and was very responsive. I'll look forward to her seminar classes.

(2) Sometimes I found things Florencia would say to be contradictory, and her explanations were not very clear.(3) I don't feel like the paper and presentation really helped me understand more about tropical forests. Maybe another kind of assignment would have been better.(4) Compared to other classes I was taking this fall, this course had less reading and fewer weekly assignments, though it was back-end heavy with a presentation and paper.(7) I didn't call upon Alvaro for help on many occasions, but his pre-midterm help session was very informative and he had a great attitude throughout the class.
I audited this class, therefore, while I really enjoyed the class sections, my knowledge of readings and assignments is limited.
The passion of the professor and her knowledge on the topic
We touched upon all of the topics that were of high interest to me.
The best thing about this course was the thoroughgoing and diversity of its content.
The material provided were really good. The Professor and the TA were always enthusiastic to teach.
Along with the subject material, Professor Montagnini's sunny disposition and sense of humor.
Straightforward
the interesting lectures
The powerpoints were filled with many pictures and graphs to bring life into the lectures and explain interesting concepts.
A wide breadth of material.

The outside-of-class assignment (a term paper) was very useful as it allowed me to explore a sub-issue of the course in greater depth than the course alone could due to time constraints. I appreciated that flexibility and the degree of choice offered by the professor.The professor's expertise in restoration added a great deal to the course, especially in her discussion of germination.
Instructor experience and knowledge

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Materials (like powerpoints) were not printer friendly, hard to keep up

Presentations were ridiculous. It was highly counterproductive to have class presentations when the students only had a bout 9 minutes to present each. It is practically impossible to deliver a solid idea or term paper topic to an audience in less than 9 minutes.
Perhaps have an outline of important information available to go along with the Powerpoints? Just the Powerpoints made taking notes difficult.
The lecture and moreover the PowerPoint presentations need to be less more concise to better fit with the time allowed.
Some more examples from the African continent.
Her slides are poorly organized. Grading was too easy - didn't learn from it.
it could use a field trip
Consistency among slides and presentations (they might need to be updated in some cases).
Please see answers on expectations below.
Not sure - maybe extend focus a little more, include more information about Africa and Asia?

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: I contacted both the TA and professor, both were extremely helpful and available
Both of them were very helpful and responsive.
Both were available whenever needed.
Excellent- both were very available and helpful.
The instructor and TA were available in all needs and the help received from them was very suitable to our request.

The instructor and TA were readily available by appointment beyond lecture periods. I had the opportunity to consult the TA on one occasion and he was extremely helpful in explaining issues and providing additional reading materials.

I contacted both the Professor and the TA at some point during the life of the course. The Professor was very helpful responding to my many questions about research and research opportunities. The TA was always available to answer questions both via email and in person.
Sought help from TA once; availability was great.
both were very responsive and helpful

Both the instructor and TA were available and encouraged contact for any assistance needed. The TA was wonderful at providing extra help; he was extremely knowledgeable and able to clearly explain concepts.
I did not call upon them for much help, but they seemed open, friendly, and receptive. Alvaro held a great pre-midterm session.
Instructor and TA were very helpful outside of class.
N/a, audited

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I had a background in Biology, and this course serves as a refresher towards the work that I am going to do in Indonesia.
I had no background in this subject. It was useful to gain background in a lot of forestry issues, not just in tropical forestry.
This course fits perfectly with my program in forestry, and moreover my interest in tropical forestry.

One of my main areas of focus is restoration ecology and this course has provided a good foundation. I deem it a necessary and ideal course for all natural resource practitioners who work or intend to work in the tropics.

Prior to this course, i had very brief interaction with a "formal" course in Tropical Forest Ecology. Much of what i knew about the tropical forests was based on my first hand experience having been born and raised and also now working in the tropics including projects in the forests. I always felt the need to learn a bit more of the formal science of "forests". Now i think i have just succeeded in doing that. In that connection , the materials and learning i acquired through this course i believe, will help me view the forest from a much detailed angle and will also help me in my management decisions
Tropical Forestry as the on-the-ground end of a study of governance issues: Areas where governance is a large problem are often areas where tropical forests are threatened and under stress.
I am focusing my program on wildlife habitat ecology and restoration, so this course provides a good foundation.
This course was an extremely important preparation for a career in tropical conservation.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am from a tropical region and it is useful for me to learn about tropical forest ecology.
To fill requirements, learn about the topic in an introductory manner
bin requirement
Highly interesetd in working in tropical rainforest environments.
I wanted to learn more about tropical ecosystems.
I took this course because I wanted to get to know about the different ecological factors influencing forest development.
Because I deem it a foundation course for all natural resource practitioners in the tropics.
To learn more about the 'formal' science of Forests
For more practical and specific knowledge to anchor my study of the large realm of governance. Also it's new and its a prerequisite to Professor Montagnini's Ecological Restoration course.
to learn about tropical forest ecology so that I can help to manage and conserve them

My interest is primarily in development which is concentrated in countries in tropical regions of the world. Conservation is closely linked to development and the two must be considered together. Learning about the ecology of tropical forests is essential to understanding the implications of activities that affect them and I took this course to gain such a foundation of tropical forest ecology knowledge.
It's a prerequisite for the ecological restorationseminar and seemed like a fun course to kick off my first semester at FES.
I wanted to learn the salient features of tropical forest ecosystems, i.e. those features that define these systems and distinguish them from others.
Career needs

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
it fell short. I was expecting to learn much more about forest ecology.
Course was a little slow and more built like an undergrad course rather than a graduate one. I Still enjoyed it though.
It was a little too basic for me.
The course partly lived up my expectations as I got additional theoritical knowledge about the ecology of the tropical forests.
Yes. To a large extent.
Very much.
no
yeah, like I said though, it would be very helpful to see and touch a tropical forest while learning about it
Yes.
Yes and no--I don't think the teaching method inspired me to work extra hard in the course, but I could have had more drive on my own and I think that I would have learned more in that case.

In general, no.The professor relied too heavily on Powerpoint slides that were full of photos and illustrations at the expense of substantive content. The course often seemed more like a survey of issues in tropical forests rather than the ecology of tropical forests. More focus should have been placed on what is known about the ecology of tropical forests as a whole, for example, nutrient cycling, energy flows, broad ecological relationships that have been deduced from numerous studies, so that the students could finish the course capable of describing the broad features of tropical forest ecosystems and also how tropical forest ecosystems are different from other forest ecosystems. While we did touch on strictly ecological topics such as nutrient cycling and the light environment, there was little integration of these important themes throughout the rest of the course. They were treated as interesting sub-topics, not as fundamental elements of the system to tie together our understanding of the whole.We spent time on topics that were interesting but not really relevant in an ecology course, for example, payments for ecosystem services and non-timber forest products.I also expected to leave the course with more specific knowledge of the most common plant taxa of tropical forest ecosystems. While names of common taxa were sprinkled throughout various lectures, an early lecture solely on this topic would have been more appropriate. This could be one of the uniting themes of a tropical forest ecology course, allowing students to predict what might be found in a given scenario based on a lecture early in the semester. Providing materials on common taxa organized by region and asking that we do some memorizing is okay!! We're not above such things. That's the kind of global perspective we need to get in the only tropical forest ecology course we're going to take at FES.More of the optional readings should have been made required. These were the more substantive readings that filled out the textbook material.
I learned what I expected to learn from this class.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
For the most part.
No, the information presented was too basic. I would want to take a course covering more advanced topics.
I got out of it with most of my expectations
Yes. To a large extent.
I expected something new and fascinating and got it
no
yep
Yes.
Yes...and I think if I reread the course lectures and readings, I would get a lot more out of them the second time around.
Isn't this the same question you just asked?
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I am really happy that the professor did not ask us to do group work.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The student needs to walk in the same frequency with the course, and he/she will need to ready a tropical project well in advance for presentation during one of the class session.
They should go for it!
Make time for the non required reading
start your presentation and term paper early on
It is helpful to utilize the main textbook to strenthen and expand concepts and ideas presented during lecture.

Buy Florencia's book for $25 with the student discount, don't pay $200+ for it! It provides material very similar to what is presented in class.Do well on the midterm because it's worth a lot of your grade and you will have a lot of work for other classes as well as this one at the end of the semester.
Do ALL the readings, not just the required ones. The required ones are too light if you expect to get a good picture of tropical forest ecology.
Take it.
